Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The type or namespace name 'Matrix4x4' could not be found" (#3179) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone `https://github.com/tzachshabtay/MonoAGS/tree/veldrid`
2. From VS for Mac, try to compile AGS.Engine.Android 

### Expected Behavior

`Matrix4x4` should be properly resolved.
From the [docs](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.numerics.matrix4x4?view=netframework-4.8) it's supported since Xamarin.Android 7.1 and I'm using 9.2.3.0.
I also tried to add `System.Numerics.Vectors` but still no go.

### Actual Behavior

Compiler error:
```
/Users/zachi/Projects/MonoAGS/Source/Engine/AGS.Engine.Desktop/Veldrid/VeldridGraphics.cs(17,17): Error CS0246: The type or namespace name 'Matrix4x4' could not be found (are you missing a using directive or an assembly reference?) (CS0246) (AGS.Engine.Android)
```

Events.RelatedBody:
In the current version of aapt2 we use we are seeing
the following error on Windows

	 error APT0000: failed parsing overlays.

Oddly it works on MacOS. Bumping to version
3.4.1-5326820 seems to fix the issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[Xamarin.Android.Build.Tasks] Resource.designer.cs should not be empty" (#3177) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/issues/3169

In 36c52c2, I fixed some of the weirdness from the test case in #3169,
but there is another problem: `Resource.designer.cs` was blank!

This is actually an issue because Xamarin.Forms 4.0 uses
`AndroidResource` files. If there is a case where
`Resource.designer.cs` isn't generated, then those resource IDs will
be incorrect--causing a crash at runtime.

Looking through the code, the sequence of events is a bit bizarre:

1. `<GenerateResourceDesigner/>` writes to a temp file using
   `MonoAndroidHelper.CopyIfStringChanged`.
2. `<CopyIfChanged/>` moves from the temp file to
   `Resources\Resource.designer.cs` if there were changes.
3. `<CreateAndroidResourceStamp/>` basically does a "touch" and
   appends a newline to `Resources.designer.cs`??? It also touches a
   stamp/flag file.

The steps didn't make sense--it seems they all will run every time.

It seemed like we just needed to clean things up:

1. `<GenerateResourceDesigner/>` writes directly to
   `Resources\Resource.designer.cs`, relying on
   `MonoAndroidHelper.CopyIfStringChanged`.
2. We get rid of `<CreateAndroidResourceStamp/>`.
3. We just use `<Touch/>` for the flag file, and add it to
   `@(FileWrites)` appropriately.

I think these changes will make this scenario a bit more reliable and
improve performance slightly.

I also updated the `AllResourcesInClassLibrary` test to verify
`Resource.designer.cs` *exists* and is non-empty.

### Steps to Reproduce
1. Debug app on device
2. App deploys
3. App tries to launch but crashes immediately

### Expected Behavior
No crash

### Actual Behavior
App crashes immediately when trying to debug on target device.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Enhancement] Add IsVisible to MenuItem" (#6440) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary

It should be possible to make MenuItems invisible if necessary, by providing a public IsVisible bindable property.

## API Changes

Add an IsVisible property to MenulItem. When set to true, the item is displayed in ContextActions, and when set to false it is hidden. The property should be bindable.

## Intended Use Case

Items in a ListView may differ from each other and may wish to present different context actions to the user.

<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
ListView shows empty cells, worked fine in XF3.6 and older.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. clone the repo at https://github.com/itoledo/XF4ListBug (it's the MasterDetail template with changes extracted from the app I'm working on)
2. check the ItemsViewModel.cs for the code. I'm using a DataTemplateSelector, which always selects the same template.
3. run the app and scroll down.

### Expected Behavior
List shows all the cells with content.

### Actual Behavior
After scrolling, some cells are empty.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: Xamarin.Forms 4.0.0.482894
- Last known good version: Xamarin.Forms 3.6.0.264807 (later versions have the iOS 10 cell height bug)
- IDE: VS2019 16.1.2
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - Android: 9.0
- Affected Devices: tested on my Nokia 7.1 with Android 9

### Screenshots
https://gfycat.com/lateshoddyaquaticleech

### Reproduction Link
https://github.com/itoledo/XF4ListBug

Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description
Setting padding in Xamarin Shell does not work to prevent the navigation bar to be drawn below Android's status bar.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. In MainActivity add:
```
this.Window.AddFlags(WindowManagerFlags.TranslucentStatus);
```
2. In AppShell.xaml add:
```
     <Shell.Padding>
        <OnPlatform x:TypeArguments="Thickness">
            <On Platform="Android">0, 24, 0, 0</On>
            <On Platform="iOS">0, 20, 0, 0</On>
        </OnPlatform>
    </Shell.Padding>
```

### Expected Behavior
Shell page title and back button appears below status bar.

### Actual Behavior
Shell page title is rendered below status bar.

- IDE: VS2019

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Shell: CollectionView or ListView content in a top tab ShellContent page is obscured behind top tabs on iOS" (#6424) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description
CollectionView or ListView content in a ShellContent's page is obscured behind the tabs on iOS. It appears that perhaps the top insets are incorrect. Video of the behavior: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_NuOoiVpHrw

Issue exists only in iOS, not Android.

Wrapping the CollectionView or ListView in a ScrollView appears to fix the insets problem, but then pull-to-refresh doesn't work because the ScrollView receives the gestures, not the nested ListView. (Not an issue for CollectionView yet, of course, because CollectionView doesn't yet support pull-to-refresh.)

I only included CollectionView in my repro sample.

### Steps to Reproduce

Build and run this sample repo:
https://github.com/jsauve/Xamarin.Forms.4.0.0.482894_TopTabs-CollectionView-Insets-Bug

### Expected Behavior

The top of the CollectionView or ListView is not obscured behind the top tabs.

### Actual Behavior

The top of the CollectionView or ListView is obscured behind the top tabs.

### Basic Information

My local dev environment details:
https://gist.github.com/jsauve/6eb67803db786def5d8f8c74b308f95d

### Screenshots

Video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_NuOoiVpHrw

### Reproduction Link

Build and run this sample repo:
https://github.com/jsauve/Xamarin.Forms.4.0.0.482894_TopTabs-CollectionView-Insets-Bug

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unable to set focus to button after selecting an Item from Picker" (#6425) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Opened issue "[Enhancement] Give the possibility to choose how many tabs should be displayed in the Xamarin.Shell tabbar " (#6438) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary
Actually, the tabbar in Xamarin.Shell display up to five tabs before resorting to the More menu.
I think five tabs are quite a lot, especially considering that the tabbar isn't optimized to show only icons (if you omit the text, the icons are aligned at the top and some empty space remains at the bottom): five string of the text could make the tabbar very crowded, especially in some languages.

## API Changes
I think the developer should be able to choose how many tabs have to been visible in the tabbar, leaving the other for the "More" menu.
Something like the Order property of the ToolbarItems could be used, to indicate if a tab should be displayed directly in the tabbar or in the menu.

## Intended Use Case
If you have five tabs with relatively long description the tabbar becomes very crowded. The proposed change would make the tabbar more aesthetically pleasant and more clear to the user.
